message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest alcoholism, which is associated with niacin deficiency. Glossitis and hyperpigmentation are also symptoms of niacin deficiency.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination suggest a deficiency in Niacin. Glossitis and the hyperpigmented rash on her face and arms are typical signs of niacin deficiency, and alcohol intake can interfere with niacin absorption.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms of alcoholic dementia, including progressive memory loss, weakness, and falls. The hyperpigmented rash and glossitis suggest a niacin deficiency, which is commonly seen in chronic alcoholics.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with symptoms that suggest niacin deficiency, including glossitis, hyperpigmented rash, and memory loss. The patient's alcoholism may have contributed to the deficiency, as alcohol decreases the body's ability to absorb and use niacin.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest alcohol abuse and malnutrition, which can lead to vitamin deficiencies. Among the options, only Vitamin B3 (niacin) deficiency can cause glossitis and a hyperpigmented rash on the face and arms. Other symptoms of vitamin B3 deficiency include dementia and diarrhea, which are also present in the patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has several symptoms that suggest a deficiency in Vitamin B3 (niacin), including diarrhea, glossitis, and skin rash. The patient also has a history of heavy alcohol consumption, which can lead to a deficiency in this vitamin. Vitamin B5 (panthothenic acid) deficiency can cause numbness and tingling in the hands and feet, while Vitamin B7 (biotin) deficiency can cause dermatitis and hair loss. Vitamin B2 (riboflavin) deficiency can cause oral and ocular symptoms, but not the other symptoms observed in this patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome, which is caused by a thiamine deficiency, specifically Vitamin B1. However, Vitamin B3 (niacin) deficiency can also cause glossitis, hyperpigmented rash, and memory loss. The fact that the patient drinks a pint of vodka daily suggests that she may have an alcohol use disorder, which can lead to a secondary Vitamin B3 deficiency.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of glossitis, hyperpigmented rash, and impaired mental status suggest a niacin deficiency, also known as pellagra. The patient’s alcohol use may be contributing to this deficiency as alcohol interferes with niacin absorption. Vitamin B5 and B7 deficiencies are rare, and Vitamin B2 deficiency can cause glossitis, but not the other symptoms present in this patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms- memory loss, weakness, diarrhea, glossitis, and the hyperpigmented rash all suggest a deficiency in niacin. The patient’s alcoholism may have contributed to this deficiency as well.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has glossitis and a hyperpigmented rash, which are common symptoms of Pellagra, a deficiency of Vitamin B3 (niacin). The patient’s alcoholism can contribute to the deficiency as alcoholism is associated with malnutrition.
